comment:
I think what is adding to her narcissism is her need to feel like Johnny will fight for her during their rough patches. Meaning that he will stay and possibly challenge her and try to get to the bottom of things. I understand that need and that frustration when someone gives you the silent treatment during a confrontation in a relationship or when they walk away or respond in very short, empty sentences. 
Maybe Johnny is guilty of responding that way to her. However, her instability and obvious narcissism in addressing her own needs and properly conveying it to Johnny leaves him confused. Even though, he puts up a decent and logical defense despite her gaslighting. Very different from the way Kaitlin responds to James when he gaslights her in that confronting way. 
So, there seems to be such a fine line because I'm sure many people can identify with Amber in not feeling fought for during an argument with their spouse. And can see how that can lead to intense frustration and possibly anger as she exhibits. But the disconnect between her and people who can relate to her is her rage. Her rage that probably contributes to her distorted perception of the reason that Johnny tries to present in his own defense. It is very sad to listen to this conversation. Because her disorder has confused him so much that he is unable to see the actions that probably fuel her rage. And also see, that she is so erratic that even if he were to see that his "splitting" makes her feel so incredible insecure about their marriage, she would be incapable of coming to resolution together about it. 
It's looks like a very complex situation. And Johnny's splitting, which in this case is the best decision he makes during their confrontations, seems to be a coping mechanism that he's developed as a result of his life experience. 
I make this observation soley based on the fact that I can relate to this situation and I choose to confront rather than split. I have some self-destructive impulse, maybe, where I confront and challenge the rageful outburts. And my response must be a coping mechanism I developed as a result of my life experience. 
I guess my ultimate point is that Amber feels hurt by Johnny and Johnny feels hurt by Amber and they both feel this and respond to this in relation to their own developed coping mechanisms that is based on their individual life experience.
Still, it seems that in this case, Johnny is being buldozed by Amber's disorder and it would be best for them to separate and work on their issues separately. We should all aspire towards continual self growth and reflection because the answers the find will always be evolving. 
And Johnny seems like he's more aware of wanting to grow than she is. She doesn't seem to be there yet.

comment:
I would like to comment that not all people with bpd act in the same way as Amber Heard did in this conversation, although she is showing mannerisms and use of language that is common with impulsive type bpd (we are unaware of any diagnosis). I have bpd (borderline type) and am in constant therapy for more self awareness for this, also with borderline personality disorder (also known as emotionally unstable personality disorder) there are two types, impulsive type: which is more quick tempered and violent in nature, often synonymous with being abusive and emotionally manipulative, often with the inability to control feelings of anger in the same way a neurotypical person would be able to and borderline type: which is more vulnerable and passive, often with the inability to control feelings of sadness, so pretty much would never act like this, and likely cannot even naturally fall into this behaviour due to being suppressed, often in childhood and therefore lacking that neural pathway. So I guess my point is: please don‚Äôt assume all of us with bpd are going to be abusive and violent and that you should never get into a relationship with anyone with bpd, some of us (granted mostly people with borderline type) are able to have healthy relationships and are not going to be manipulative and abusive

Edit: also I do not mean this as criticism to you and your analysis of this situation, more to spread the awareness that bpd isn‚Äôt always how Amber heard is :)
